DataElement.preferredName: Bone Marrow Biopsy Myeloid Erythroid Ratio Character Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Ratio of myeloid to erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.  Usually 3-4:1 in a normal marrow.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Bone Marrow Biopsy Myeloid Erythroid Ratio Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The soft, sponge-like tissue in the center of bones that produces white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets._Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body._(MYE-eh-loyd) Pertaining to, derived from, or manifesting certain features of the bone marrow. In some cases also pertains to certain types of non-lymphocyte white blood cells found in the bone marrow, including granulocyte, monocyte, and platelet lineages. Also called myelogenous._1) Reddish in color. 2) relating to erythrocytes or their precursors._The ratio of two or more signals, typically between two channels.  Of type float. (caMAGE)_The result of an action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The soft tissue filling the cavities of bones. Bone marrow exists in two types, yellow and red. Yellow marrow is found in the large cavities of large bones and consists mostly of fat cells and a few primitive blood cells. Red marrow is a hematopoietic tissue and is the site of production of erythrocytes and granular leukocytes. Bone marrow is made up of a framework of connective tissue containing branching fibers with the frame being filled with marrow cells (MSH98):Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: (MYE-eh-loyd) Pertaining to, derived from, or manifesting certain features of the bone marrow. In some cases also pertains to certain types of non-lymphocyte white blood cells found in the bone marrow, including granulocyte, monocyte, and platelet lineages. Also called myelogenous.:1) Reddish in color. 2) relating to erythrocytes or their precursors.:The ratio of two or more signals, typically between two channels.  Of type float. (caMAGE):The result of an action.

Concepts.definition: A type of white blood cell. Neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils are granulocytes.
1) Reddish in color. 2) relating to erythrocytes or their precursors.
Quotient of quantities of the same kind for different components within the same system.
